awd_abstract_narration:
All cells are surrounded by a membrane that keeps undesirable molecules (like toxins) from entering, but allows the passage of nutrients into the cell, and waste products out.  The ability of nature to control the types of molecules that pass through the membrane is central to biological function.  Nature accomplishes this task by embedding proteins with complex chemical structures into the membrane.  These proteins form small channels that allow specific molecules through, but reject others.  While the importance of natural channels in biology is well-appreciated, the design of artificial channels that exhibit the same functionality as their biological analogs is immensely challenging.  In this research project, Professor George Gokel at the University of Missouri-Saint Louis is studying the transport capabilities of relatively simple molecules inserted into lipid membranes.  The ability to create artificial membrane channels that mediate the passage of specific molecules could impact applications ranging from biology and medicine to water purification, problems with significant societal importance.  In addition, this project is providing scientific training of graduate students and postdoctoral scholars in interdisciplinary science. 

Controlling insertion into a membrane, manipulating the selectivity and direction of ion and molecule transport, and understanding the organization of the membrane around the channels, present major challenges in supramolecular chemistry.  With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry program in the Division of Chemistry, the Gokel Lab develops a variety of novel structures that penetrate lipid bilayers and selectively transport cations and molecules through the membranes.  This research enhances understanding of membrane penetrating compounds by using a plethora of techniques to interrogate their properties and functional mechanisms.  The long-term goal is to establish fundamental principles for designing synthetic structures that can substitute complex proteins in mediating the passage of specific molecules into specific types of cells.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Well characterized hydraphiles functioned both as antibiotics and potency-enhancing adjuvants. The question was how they functioned ― as permeability enhancers or disrupters of ion homeostasis or both. Ion disruption could result from carrier or channel function. The effort was therefore to better understand membrane penetration and the mechanism of ion transport, if any. A further goal was to determine the optimal structural dependence of the various amphiphiles. A benefit of the research effort was that various molecules were screened for biological activity. This resulted in several candidates as antimicrobial adjuvants that recover various antibiotics to which resistance has developed.

Specific objectives. The three specific objectives in the research plan remained unchanged.

Specific aim one results. We developeda family of bis(tryptophan) [bis(Trp); BT] amphiphiles at the end of the previous project. The compounds prepared were of the general form H2N-Trp-spacer-Trp-NH2(W-spacer-W). The pendant indole residue present in tryptophan along with the protonated amines were expected to sustain amphiphilic behavior. Planar bilayer voltage clamp studies showed clear evidence for pore/channel formation. Results were reported for W-o-C6H4-W, W-m-C6H4-W, and W-C12-W inAntibiotics,2021,10, 1391. Evidence both for enhanced membrane penetration and permeability was obtained with propidium iodide (PI, fluorescence assay, Staphylococcus aureus). A concentration dependent increase in fluorescence was observed for W-C12-W along with 128-fold enhanced antibiotic potency of norfloxacin. The data showed that synergy rather than additivity occurred. Similar structures were prepared with non-Trp amino acids. Compounds of the form H2N-Aaa-m-C6H4-Aaa-NH2were Phe, Tyr, Leu, Ala, Pro, Thr, and Lys. None of these compounds showed any biological or planar bilayer activity.Data are in U.S. Patent 11,213,512 (January 4, 2022) titled “Bis-Amino Acid Based Compound and Use Thereof" (NSF funding).

Results obtained under specific aim two. Di-n-alkyldiaza-18-crown-6 compounds show antimicrobial activity. This may result from carrier-type ion transport, by aggregated pore formation, or both. During the project, dialkyllariats and their hydrochloride and methiodide salts all functioned as antimicrobial adjuvants and exhibited channel function.

We developed a tetracycline-resistantE. colistrain (MIC ~1000 µM) that showed a MIC of 87 in the persence of ½ MIC of di-C11lariat ether (C11LE).This potency enhancement is ~12-fold. NMR experiments (CD2Cl2) determined that tetracycline, which isinsoluble in CD2Cl2, formed a 1:1 complex with C10LE.Similar studies on ampicillin and penicillin G, each of which formed a 4:1 complex (crown:drug).Further confirmation of complexation between C10LE and tetracycline was obtained by sonicating the crown. It formed stable liposomes in water. When a mixture of C10LE and tetracycline (1:1) was sonicated in water, no liposomes could be detected.

Results obtained under specific aim three. Planar bilayer studies confirmed ion transport mediated by aggregated lariat ethers (ChemBioChem2016DOI: 10.1002/cbic.201600428). The planar bilayer experiment does not give information about the level of membrane penetration. Instead, neutron reflectance studies were undertaken and are described in a manuscript submitted to ChemBioChem. Neutron reflectance allows direct observation of crown+antimicrobial within a silicon-anchored bilayer.To our knowledge, this is the first such visualization of a supramolecular complex within a bilayer membrane.

Additional evidence was obtained by using eitherE. coliorS. aureus. We probed the system by using the fluorescent dyes propidium iodide (PI) and alamar blue. PI does not penetrate bacterial membranes. Alamar blue is metabolized in vital bacteria to resofurin, which demonstrates that permeability is not due to cellular lysis.S. aureusshowed PI fluorescence in the absence of any additive to the extent of ~7500 relative fluorescence units (RFUs). Added C10LE increased PI fluorescence to ~23,000 RFU. Alamar blue fluorescence confirmed cellular vitality.

Enhanced permeability allows greater antimicrobial membrane penetration Disruption of ion homeostasis hobbles efflux pump function. A range of compounds was compared to reserpine, the efflux pump standard. Compared to reserpine, C10LE•2HCl was threefold more effective at 0.2-fold the concentration or 15-fold more potent at inhibiting the NorA efflux pumps inS. aureus. Similar results were obtained for various other amphiphiles.

Summary. First, thebis(tryptophan) (BT) amphiphiles are pore-formers, they are antimicrobials,and they function as potency enhancing adjuvants for antimicrobials against several resistant organisms. They are also active against Mycobacterium tuberculosis. They form liposomes and insert into bacterial membranes. Similar compounds in which tryptophan was replaced by other common 20 amino acids failed to exhibit any of these properties.

Second, simple lariat ether compounds possess the surprising ability to enhance the penetration of antimicrobials into membranes. Several lariat ethers form 1:1 complexes with tetracycline and minocycline. Other drugs are also complexed, but in different ratios. Some closely related drugs give very different complexation results.

Third, in collaboration with Dr. Harshita Kumari and others, we have demonstrated that neutron reflectance can be used to directly confirm both penetration of tetracycline into a bilayer membrane and the enhancement of that penetration mediated by a dialklyldiazalariat ether.


Last Modified: 01/19/2022
Modified by: George W Gokel
